p.value: Materials are open without restrictions.
Materials found in collection; there is no documentation concerning the provenance of these materials. The accession number associated with this collection is 14.020.

The H. Robert Otness Collection of New York City Postcards and Photographs is arranged by format on the series level.  Within each series, materials are arranged into folders alphabetically. Within the first series of postcards, landmarks that were especially well represented in the collection, such as the Chrysler Building and Washington Square Park, received their own dedicated folders. Other postcards are arranged in topical folders.

The second series contains photographs that were found in two small envelopes in the collection.  The photographs were retained in their original order and placed within two folders corresponding to their respective envelopes.
The collection is arranged in three series:
I. Postcards
II. Personal Materials
III. Photographs

Herman Robert Otness was born in Moscow, Idaho, in 1907. He attended New York University between 1935 and 1939, graduating with a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from the School of Education in 1939. It was during these years at NYU that Otness may have collected the postcards and took the photographs that make up this collection.

After graduating from NYU, Otness worked as the chief clinical psychologist at The Training School in Vineland, New Jersey. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. In 1950 he accepted a position as associate professor of psychology at the University of Idaho, where he remained until his retirement in 1971. Otness died in Moscow, Idaho on April 21, 1995.

Sources:
1.  Judith Nielsen, "Herman Robert Otness," University of Idaho Special Collections and Archives, March 1997.  Accessed June 6, 2014.  http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/special-collections/Manuscripts/mg379.htm.
2.  New York University Commencement program, 1939.

abstract.value: The H. Robert Otness Collection of New York City Postcards and Photographs contains postcards and a small number of photographs that document New York City's landmarks as they appeared in the 1930s.  The collection was likely created by H. Robert Otness, who earned a Ph.D. from New York University in 1939.

physloc.value: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

unittitle.value: H. Robert Otness Collection of New York City Postcards and Photographs

p.value: Series I includes postcards depicting New York City landmarks as they appeared in the 1930s. Landmarks that are particularly well documented in the collection include the city's churches, bridges, museums, hotels, and theaters, as well as the Chrysler Building, Empire State Building, Rockefeller Center, and the Washington Square Arch.

unittitle.value: Washington Square and the Queen Mary

p.value: Series II includes a small number of photographs presumably taken by Otness during the same time period. Their subject matter is largely similar to that of the postcards in the collection: Washington Square Park is heavily featured, as is the RMS Queen Mary (which completed its first transatlantic voyage to New York in 1936), and the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

p.value: Series III includes ephemera collected by Otness while studying at NYU.
Identification of item, date; H. Robert Otness Collection of New York City Postcards; MC 245; box number; folder number or item identifier; Repository Name, New York University.
Decisions regarding arrangement, description, and physical interventions for this collection prior to 2018 are unknown. In 2019 materials were rehoused by Preservation and sent to offsite storage.
For additional information about Otness, see the Herman Robert Otness Papers at the University of Idaho's Special Collections and Archives.

The bulk of the collection contains postcards depicting New York City landmarks as they appeared in the 1930s. Landmarks that are particularly well documented in the collection include the city's churches, bridges, museums, hotels, and theaters, as well as the Chrysler Building, Empire State Building, Rockefeller Center, and the Washington Square Arch. There is a small number of photographs presumably taken by Otness during the same time period. Their subject matter is largely similar to that of the postcards in the collection: Washington Square Park is heavily featured, as is the RMS Queen Mary (which completed its first transatlantic voyage to New York in 1936), and the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Materials also include ephemera collected by Otness while studying at NYU.

Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by H. Robert Otness are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, 212-998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu
2014
